post_title: The US and UK are teaming up to test the safety of AI models
title: US, UK Join AI Safety Partnership to Evaluate Models
post_content:
In recent years, the development of generative AI models has skyrocketed, with companies like OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic constantly improving their technologies. However, as these models become more advanced, there is a growing concern about their safety. To address this issue, the UK and US governments have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to establish a common approach for evaluating the safety of AI models.

Under this partnership, the UK's AI Safety Institute and its counterpart in the US will collaborate to develop suites of tests that assess the risks and ensure the safety of the most advanced AI models. They plan to share technical knowledge, information, and personnel as part of this collaboration. One of their initial goals is to perform a joint testing exercise on a publicly accessible model.

According to the Financial Times, this partnership is the first bilateral arrangement on AI safety in the world. Both the US and the UK aim to work with other countries in the future, as AI is the defining technology of our generation, and this partnership will accelerate their work across the full spectrum of risks.

While this partnership is focused on testing and evaluation, governments around the world are also conjuring regulations to keep AI tools in check. In March, the White House signed an executive order aimed at ensuring that federal agencies are only using AI tools that do not endanger the rights and safety of the American people. A couple of weeks before that, the European Parliament approved sweeping legislation to regulate artificial intelligence. The legislation bans "AI that manipulates human behavior or exploits people's vulnerabilities," "biometric categorization systems based on sensitive characteristics," as well as the "untargeted scraping" of faces from CCTV footage and the web to create facial recognition databases. Additionally, deepfakes and other AI-generated images, videos, and audio will need to be clearly labeled as such under its rules.

Overall, the partnership between the UK and US governments, as well as the regulations being put in place around the world, highlight the growing concern about the safety of AI models. It is crucial that we continue to develop a common approach for evaluating the safety of these models and ensure that they are used for the benefit of society without posing a threat to it.

post_title: Researchers set new efficiency record for stable binary organic solar cells
title: "Researchers achieve record PCE of 19.7% in stable binary OSCs using asymmetric SAMs"
post_content:
The pursuit of highly efficient and stable organic solar cells (OSCs) has been a long-standing challenge in the field of organic electronic devices. Recently, a research group led by Prof. Ge Ziyi from the Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology and Engineering (NIMTE) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences developed two self-assembled molecules (SAMs) that have large dipole moments and employed them as hole-transporting layers (HTLs) in binary OSCs, achieving highly efficient and stable binary OSCs with a record power conversion efficiency (PCE) of up to 19.70%.

The development of new materials and optimization of the fabrication process have contributed to the rapid improvement in the PCE of OSCs, which has exceeded 19%. However, achieving a balance between efficiency and stability in conventional OSCs still remains a challenge. To address this issue, the researchers designed and synthesized two asymmetric SAMs with asymmetric backbone, namely BrCz and BrBACz. The two SAMs served as HTLs in binary OSCs based on the well-known system of PM6:Y6, PM6:eC9, PM6:L8-BO, and D18:eC9, respectively.

Compared with conventional PEDOT:PSS-controlled OSCs, the BrCz-controlled and BrBACz-controlled OSCs exhibited higher transmittance, deeper work function, and lower surface energy, thus realizing enhanced hole extraction, increased hole mobility, decreased interface resistance, and reduced carrier recombination. The BrBACz-based OSC achieved a record high PCE of 19.70% with a remarkable current density of 29.20 mA cm-2 and a circuit voltage of 0.856 V, which is the highest value reported to date for binary OSCs.

When exposed to ambient air (40 ± 5% humidity) and continuous illumination for 1,036 hours, the BrBACz-controlled device can maintain up to 95.0% of its initial efficiency, which is the best air stability for the conventional OSCs. In addition, the BrBACz-controlled device also plays a remarkable role in other well-known binary systems, such as PM6:Y6, PM6:L8-BO, and D18:eC9, demonstrating its excellent generality.

This work highlights the importance of rational molecular structure design in the development of highly efficient and stable OSCs. By optimizing the molecular structure, the researchers were able to achieve a remarkable improvement in the performance of binary OSCs. This work paves the way for the future development and application of highly efficient and stable OSCs in various fields.

post_title: Instagram's upcoming Blend feature may finally put its short-form videos ahead of TikTok
post_content:
Instagram is working on a new feature called Blend, which will allow you and a friend to enjoy a private collection of Reels together. The feature will be based on Reels that you've shared with others as well as those that both you and your friend have shown interest in. With Blend, you can create a private feed between you and your friend and leave it at any time.

For those who are new to Instagram, a Reel is simply a short video on the platform. Any user can record and post a 15-second video with an audio track and special effects. With a private account, you can share your Reels with just your followers or close friends. With a public account, you can share your Reels with anyone on Instagram to watch.

To access a Reel, simply tap the Reels icon in the iOS or Android mobile app or on the website. Swipe or scroll up and down to watch each video. With the icons on the right, you can like, comment on, share, or listen to the audio from any Reel.

Instagram uses several tricks to direct you to Reels you may like. The app suggests Reels liked by someone you follow, Reels you've already watched, and posts you've liked or saved. Resharing a Reel, watching it until the end, or checking out the Reel's page are other signs that you might watch similar Reels.

A feature like Blend could potentially expand the reach and engagement of a Reel by letting two people discover and enjoy the same videos together. Plus, Blend could be another feature that helps Instagram keep up with fellow video sharing platform TikTok, as the two battle for users and advertising dollars.

Last November, Instagram rolled out several new Reels features. You can now share your Reels with just close friends instead of all your followers. To spruce up a video during the editing phase, you can scale, crop, rotate clips, and undo and redo edits.

post_title: Apple researchers develop AI that can 'see' and understand screen context
title: Apple's ReALM: AI Breakthrough in Voice Assistant Context Understanding
post_content:
Title: Unlocking Natural Interactions: Apple's New AI System Revolutionizes Voice Assistants

Introduction:
Voice assistants are becoming increasingly popular, offering hands-free convenience for users. However, one challenge these assistants face is understanding ambiguous references to on-screen entities, which requires processing both conversational and background context. To address this issue, Apple researchers have developed a groundbreaking artificial intelligence system named ReALM (Reference Resolution As Language Modeling). Let's delve into the capabilities of this innovative technology and discover how it enhances the user experience.

Understanding Context and Visual Elements:
ReALM converts the intricate process of reference resolution—including comprehending references to visual components on a display—into a straightforward language modeling concern. Using large language models, ReALM significantly improves performance compared to traditional approaches. According to Apple's researchers, "being able to understand context, including references, is vital for a conversational assistant." They emphasize that allowing users to query information based on their screen content paves the way for seamless, hands-free experiences.

Key Innovations and Improvements:
To manage screen-based references effectively, ReALM constructs a textual depiction of the screen through parsed on-screen entities and their positions. Fine-tuning language models explicitly for reference resolution enables ReALM to surpass previous state-of-the-art results, such as those achieved by GPT-4. Notably, small and large models alike show considerable improvement over existing systems, making ReALM a promising solution for various real-world scenarios.

Applications and Limitations:
This novel method underscores the significance of targeted language models capable of handling tasks like reference resolution efficiently, particularly in settings where deploying colossal end-to-end models might not be feasible due to latency or computational restrictions. With ReALM, Apple continues to advance its virtual assistant, Siri, along with other context-aware offerings while acknowledging certain challenges, such as dealing with sophisticated visual cues requiring computer vision integration and multi-modal techniques.

Competing in the AI Race:
While Apple pursues AI excellence, fierce competitors like Google, Microsoft, Amazon, and OpenAI lead the charge in commercializing generative AI solutions across numerous domains. Anticipated announcements during Apple's WWDC conference in June include a new large language model framework, an "Apple GPT" chatbot, and additional AI-driven features throughout its ecosystem. Although Apple boasts robust finances, loyal customer base, top-notch engineers, and integrated hardware and software, time will tell whether these advantages suffice in the highly competitive AI arena.

Conclusion:
As the world eagerly awaits technological advances at the upcoming WWDC, expectations remain high for Apple's contributions to reshaping the future of artificial intelligence and hands-free interaction. Through innovations like ReALM, the company demonstrates its commitment to improving voice assistance technologies, setting the stage for smoother, more intuitive user experiences in the era of ubiquitous, genuinely smart computing.

post_content:
[INTRODUCTION]
Google has recently made headlines with a significant move to safeguard user privacy. The tech giant announced that it would replace tracking software 'cookies' in its popular Chrome browser, aiming to strike a balance between effective advertising and privacy protection. In addition, Google has agreed to delete a vast amount of search data, settling a lawsuit concerning the tracking of millions of US users who believed they were browsing privately in Chrome's Incognito Mode.

[GOOGLE'S PRIVACY COMMITMENT]
Google's commitment to privacy becomes evident as they work on replacing cookies with a new method that targets ads while preserving user privacy. The lawsuit, originally filed in June 2020, sought at least $5 billion in damages. It alleged that Google had deceived users by offering an 'Incognito Mode' in the Chrome browser, creating a false sense of privacy while still tracking online activities. The lawsuit emphasized the immense power Google holds in gathering detailed and expansive information about individuals' lives, interests, and internet usage.

[GOOGLE'S SETTLEMENT TERMS]
Under the proposed settlement, Google will block third-party tracking 'cookies' by default in Incognito Mode for the next five years. Cookies are small files employed to track web navigation and are used to target advertising. Google has faced increasing regulation regarding cookies, including the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation and California's privacy laws.

[GOOGLE'S DELAYED ELIMINATION OF THIRD-PARTY COOKIES]
Google initially announced in 2020 that it would eliminate third-party cookies within two years. However, the process has faced multiple delays due to opposition from web media publishers. Meanwhile, the company has already begun limiting third-party cookies for some users of the Chrome browser.

post_title: Scientists develop high-boost and high-efficiency DC power converter
title: High-Efficiency Direct Current (DC) Voltage Boost Converter
post_content:
Title: Kobe University Develops High-Efficiency Direct Current Voltage Boost Converter 

Are you tired of bulky and expensive power supplies that generate a lot of noise and heat? Look no further! The Kobe University-developed direct current voltage boost converter is here to change that. This innovative device achieves a much higher efficiency than before, at a lower cost and with reduced maintenance, making it a significant contribution to the development of electric and electronic components across various industries.

Direct current voltage boost converters are essential components in many devices that convert low-voltage direct current into high-voltage direct current output. These devices are used in various applications, including solar panels, medical devices, and hydrogen-fueled cars. However, the main challenge of these devices is to operate at high efficiency without generating electromagnetic noise or heat, while using as few parts as possible.

The Kobe University power electronics research team, led by researcher Mishima Tomokazu, has made a breakthrough in developing a new direct current power conversion circuit that solves this problem. The team combined high-frequency switching (about 10 times higher than before) with a technique that reduces electromagnetic noise and power losses due to heat dissipation, called "soft switching," while also reducing the number of components and, therefore, keeping cost and complexity low.

"When the circuit changes between two states, there is a brief period when the switch is not completely closed, and at that point, there is both a voltage and a current across the switch. This means that during this time, the switch acts like a resistor and thus dissipates heat. The more often a switch state changes, the more this dissipation occurs. Soft switching is a technique that guarantees that the switch transitions happen at zero voltage, thus minimizing the heat loss," explains Dr. Mishima.

The Kobe University team presented their new circuit design and its evaluation in the journal IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics. The key to their achievement is the use of "resonant tank" circuits that can store energy during the switching period and therefore have much lower losses. In addition, they use a component-saving design with flat components printed onto a circuit board, called a "planar transformer," which is very compact and has both good efficiency and thermal performance.

Mishima and his colleagues also built a prototype of the circuit and measured its performance. They confirmed that their snubberless design has much reduced electromagnetic noise and a high energy efficiency of up to 91.3%, which is unprecedented for a MHz drive with high voltage conversion ratio. This ratio is also more than 1.5 times higher than existing designs.

Considering how ubiquitous electrical devices are in our society, the high-efficiency and low-noise operation of direct current power supplies with a high voltage multiplier ratio is extremely important. This Kobe University development will be of great relevance to applications in electric power, renewable energy, transportation, information and telecommunications, and medical care.

"The current development is a 100W-class small-capacity prototype, but we aim to expand the power capacity to a larger kW-class capacity in the future by improving the electronic circuit board and other components," says Dr. Mishima.

In recent years, manufacturers have been demanding very stringent purity specifications from cathode material suppliers to ensure consistent output. One of the significant challenges in the production of high-quality cathode materials is the requirement for extremely low levels of impurities. This finding has significant implications for the battery industry, as it suggests that manufacturers need to reevaluate their cathode material specifications and consider more unconventional approaches.

The Internet of Things (IoT) has revolutionized the way we interact with devices and the environment. However, powering these devices with traditional sources of energy has limitations, as they require frequent charging or rely on finite resources. Therefore, researchers have turned their attention to using ambient energy sources such as wind and human motion to power IoT devices. Electrostatic generators (ESGs) have emerged as a promising solution for this purpose, as they can efficiently convert environmental energy into electricity. However, the effectiveness of ESGs has been hindered by an impedance mismatch between the generator and the electronic device, resulting in low energy utilization efficiency. In this article, we will discuss a recent study that has developed a high-performance energy management unit (EMU) designed to significantly boost the efficiency of ESGs for IoT applications.

Body:

ESGs have gained significant attention as a sustainable and cost-effective method for powering low-power devices in IoT networks. These generators can harness energy from various sources, including wind, human motion, and vibrations, making them ideal for remote and off-grid applications. However, the effectiveness of ESGs has been restricted by an impedance mismatch when connected to electronic devices, which results in low energy utilization efficiency. This challenge has hindered the widespread adoption of ESGs for IoT applications.

A team of researchers from Microsystems & Nanoengineering has developed an efficient EMU that addresses the longstanding challenge of impedance mismatch, significantly boosting the power efficiency of ESGs for IoT devices. The study demonstrates that the EMU increased the performance of contact-separated triboelectric nanogenerators by 50%, and the power efficiency of rotary electret generators by 35%. These results highlight the versatility of the EMU across different energy-harvesting technologies.

The EMU comprises a spark-switch tube and a buck converter, which has been meticulously optimized to enhance the power efficiency of ESGs. The spark-switch tube facilitates the conversion of ambient energy into electrical energy, while the buck converter regulates the voltage and current output, ensuring optimal performance. The study shows that the EMU led to an unprecedented direct current output of 79.2 mW m-2 rps-1 in rotary electret generators, representing a significant leap in efficiency.

The development of this EMU has significant implications for the practical application of ESGs in IoT devices. The enhanced efficiency and reliability of self-powered IoT devices will make them more viable for use in remote and sustainable applications. Furthermore, the broad adoption of ESGs will facilitate the growth of IoT networks, enabling the integration of various devices and sensors, leading to more innovative and efficient solutions.

post_content:
Two-dimensional (2D) materials are being increasingly used in the development of miniaturized optoelectronic devices. These devices require high gate capacitance to perform optimally while consuming less energy. However, increasing gate capacitance often requires reducing the thickness of gate insulators or dielectrics, which can lead to decreased performance or increased complexity.

To overcome this challenge, researchers at Fudan University have developed a 2D perovskite oxide with high dielectric constant (κ) that can be integrated with different 2D channel materials. The perovskite oxide, Sr 2 Nb 3 O 10 , was synthesized using a top-down approach and has a high κ of 24.6, making it a promising photoactive high-κ dielectric for phototransistors.

The research team transferred the Sr 2 Nb 3 O 10 nanosheets onto various 2D materials, including graphene, molybdenum disulfide, tungsten disulfide and tungsten diselenide. They then tested the performance of transistors integrating these materials with Sr 2 Nb 3 O 10 . The findings were highly promising, with molybdenum disulfide transistors exhibiting an on/off ratio of 106 and tungsten disulfide phototransistors showing a photocurrent-to-dark-current ratio of ~106 and UV responsivity of 5.5 × 103 A W−1.

The well-defined interface established between the semiconductor and dielectric, along with the high-κ of Sr 2 Nb 3 O 10 , enabled efficient gate control of channel materials. Furthermore, the phototransistors with the photoactive dielectric could offer UV-visible dual-band photodetection, where UV and visible light illumination were distinguished at separate terminals.

This research has the potential to pave the way for the synthesis of additional 2D perovskite oxides that can be integrated with existing semiconductors and channel materials. These 2D perovskite oxides could be used to develop smaller, better performing, and energy-efficient electronics or optoelectronics.

In conclusion, the development of high dielectric constant (high-κ) gate dielectrics compatible with 2D semiconductors is essential for scaled optoelectronic devices. Title: The Limitations of Artificial Intelligence in Stock Picking

Are you ready to revolutionize your stock picking with artificial intelligence? Think again! Despite the hype, current technology falls far short of what is needed to make intelligent choices. In this article, we will explore the limitations of GPTs in the stock market and why they cannot make basic decisions.

First, an analysis of all the stock-picking GPTs in OpenAI's GPT marketplace shows that every single one fails an extremely simple test: They cannot tell you if a stock is expensive or cheap. The question of what's expensive does not mean which stock price is the highest in absolute dollars, euros, or renminbi. Instead, it means which stock has the highest of one of several stock valuation metrics. Usually, that metric is a ratio, such as the price of the shares listed at the moment divided by some piece of financial data.

ChatGPT, and the various GPTs, don't know that basic fact. Every single one of them answers in the same clueless way. They mostly cite the recent stock price of Berkshire Hathaway, the company run by billionaire investor Warren Buffett. Berkshire's stock price, at last check, was $634,440, so it's the highest price of all stocks in absolute dollars.

However, this does not mean Berkshire is the most expensive. It doesn't even mean it's expensive at all. Depending on the earnings per share, Berkshire stock might not be expensive. If the ratio is lower than the ratio for other stocks, Berkshire might be cheap compared to many stocks even though you would need to have a fortune to buy one share.

In other words, the GPTs haven't actually addressed the question. In fact, they're missing entirely the question of valuation, the ratio, implied by the question. The failure of every single GPT to answer that very basic question has significant implications. First, the fact that every one of them produces more or less the same answer suggests they are all drawing from some similar misconception. That's probably coming from the pre-training data in OpenAI's GPT itself, which is obviously shaped by some collection of conversational data that confuses share price for valuation.

More important, the GPTs clearly don't "understand" the question, even though they are in many cases connected to a remote service that presumably is domain-specific for the investing domain. Many of the GPTs ask your permission to contact a remote host, suggesting they're accessing a database. The fact that the programs can't parse a very basic question suggests that despite outside resources, nothing has been done to refine -- or "fine-tune," as it's called -- their grasp of patterns of speech in the domain of stock-picking.

When the question is phrased more specifically, about which stocks have the "highest P/E," the GPTs fail again. They claim not to have access to sufficient real-time information -- which is surprising for programs that, again, are phoning home to outside services. The GPTs are clearly at a primitive stage of development, given that it's very easy to look up the current P/E of any stock by going to Yahoo! Finance and searching for that stock. The P/E of Apple and others are listed among the most basic information about the stocks.

It's impossible to stress too much the importance of the basic question of how expensive or cheap a stock is. If you can't handle this simple question, you really can't do any stock investing at all. That means all of the stock investing GPTs at the moment are useless. They may produce a variety of data about companies and stocks, but nothing that would give any valuable insight.

post_title: The AltStore, an alternative app store coming to the EU, will offer Patreon-backed apps
title: EU Launches Alternative App Store: AltStore Offers Patreon-Backed Apps
post_content:
Apple's long-standing hold on the App Store ecosystem for iPhone apps may be coming to an end thanks to the European Union's Digital Markets Act (DMA). The DMA aims to encourage competition by allowing third-party app stores to distribute apps independently of the App Store. One such app store is the AltStore, an alternative app marketplace that's preparing to launch a new version in the EU.

The AltStore will be similar in some ways to Apple's own App Store, but it will also allow developers to monetize their apps using a unique business model. Instead of relying on ads, paid downloads, or in-app purchases, the AltStore will allow developers to use its custom Patreon integration to market their apps directly to consumers.

The AltStore plans to launch in the EU with just two apps, Delta and Clip. Delta will be available for free, while Clip will require a pledge of $1 or more on Patreon. The AltStore will also allow other developers to distribute their apps through the storefront, with the ability to use the same Patreon integration to monetize their apps.

One of the key advantages of the AltStore is the ability to provide users with a "granular view" of the entitlements that an app has, before installing it. This will give users more control over their app downloads and allow them to choose apps that align with their values and preferences.

The AltStore is set to launch now, but Testut is waiting for final approval from Apple. If successful, the AltStore will provide users with a new way to discover and download apps, while also giving developers a new way to monetize their content.

post_content:
In March 2020, Astra's Rocket 3.0 suffered a catastrophic failure during prelaunch testing at Alaska's Pacific Spaceport Complex. The explosion, initially reported as an "anomaly," left the rocket destroyed and ended Astra's third orbital launch attempt.

At the time, Astra CEO Chris Kemp downplayed the incident, telling TechCrunch that the rocket had "suffered an anomaly following an otherwise successful day of testing." However, the video footage obtained by TechCrunch showed the micro launcher bursting into flames, indicating that the vehicle did not survive.

Astra was taking the failures in stride, with CEO Chris Kemp stating in a May 2022 interview that reliability was not the end goal. The company believed that so many launches would be successful that people would stop thinking about them.

Despite its initial success, Astra failed to materialize its ultra-low-cost launch plans, and after months of burning cash, the company's board accepted a take-private deal from Kemp and CTO Adam London at a stock price of just $0.50 per share. The deal is expected to close this quarter, and Astra will cease trading on the Nasdaq.

Astra did not respond to a request for comment on the 2020 launch failure.
